title: The inverse function theorem
text: The inverse function theorem is that (f**(-1))'*(x)=1/(f'*(f**-1)*(x)).
speech: The inverse function theorem is that (f**(-1))'*(x)=1/(f'*(f**-1)*(x)).
pacedSpeech: The inverse function theorem is that (f**(-1))'*(x)=1/(f'*(f**-1)*(x)).

title: Finding the Inverse of f(x) at $$a=0$$.
text: To find the inverse of f(x) where $$a=0$$, then we need to first find what value of $$x$$ when we plug it into f(x) will give us a value of $$0$$. In this case, it is when $$x=0$$, so we know that $$0f^{\left(-1\right)}=0$$.
speech: To find the inverse of f(x) where  a is equal to, 0 , then we need to first find what value of  x  when we plug it into f(x) will give us a value of  0 . In this case, it is when  x is equal to 0 , so we know that  0, f raised to the parentheses negative 1  power is equal to 0 .

title: Finding the derivative of f(x)
text: Next, to find the derivative of f(x), we can use the power rule. To do this, we can multiply the coefficient of each $$x$$ by its current exponent, and then subtract $$1$$ from the exponent. Remember, constants become $$0$$ when we take the derivative of a function and the derivative of tan(x) is $${sec}^2 x$$.

Remember, constants become  0  when we take the derivative of a function and the derivative of tan(x) is  secant squared of x .

title: Applying the Inverse Function Theorem
text: Since we already found $$0f^{\left(-1\right)}=0$$ and the derivative of f(x), then we can plug what we know into the inverse function theorem.
speech: Since we already found  0, f raised to the parentheses negative 1  power is equal to 0  and the derivative of f(x), then we can plug what we know into the inverse function theorem.
